sen.j: 普茶料理（ふちゃりょうり）は、江戸時代初期に中国からもたらされた日本の精進料理。
sen.e: Fucha ryori is Japanese vegetarian cuisine introduced from China in the early Edo period.

sen.j: 葛と植物油を多く使った濃厚な味。
sen.e: It is characterized by its rich flavor using plenty of kuzu (arrowroot) and vegetable oil, and the eating style of four diners sitting around one table is also distinctive.

sen.e: Representative fucha ryori are shojin unagi (vegetarian dish which looks like broiled eel) and sesame tofu.

sen.e: In the early Edo period (about 300 years ago), when the Ming dynasty declined, the Obaku sect of Zen Buddhism was introduced from China.

sen.j: 彼らが持ち込んだ当時の中国式の精進料理（いわゆる素菜）が、普茶料理である。
sen.e: A Chinese-style vegetarian set meal (so-called sozai) of the day which was brought to Japan by them was fucha ryori.

sen.j: 一つの長方形の座卓を4人で囲み、一品ずつの大皿料理を分け合って食べるという様式が非常に珍しがられた。
sen.e: Four people sit around a rectangular low table and share each prepared dish served on a large platter, which was regarded as a novel style of eating.

sen.j: 料理においても中国風のものが多く、「雲片」と呼ばれる野菜の炒め煮や胡麻豆腐、「もどき」料理（山芋の蒲焼など）などがある。
sen.e: Fucha ryori includes many Chinese-style dishes such as sautéed vegetables called 'unpen', sesame tofu, and 'fake' dish (broiled yam which looks like broiled eel).

sen.j: 炒めや揚げといった中国風の調理技術には胡麻油が用いられ、日本では未発達であった油脂利用を広めた。
sen.e: Though it was not common for Japanese people in those days to use oil in cooking, sesame oil was used in the Chinese cooking such as stir-frying and deep-frying, therefore the use of oil became popular in Japan.

sen.j: 「普茶」とは「茶を普く」という意味であり、煎茶普及の一翼を担った。
sen.e: Fucha' means 'to spread tea widely,' and fucha ryori made a contribution to the popularity of drinking green tea.

sen.j: こうした普茶料理は、精進料理というよりは異国情緒を味わうものとして黄檗宗の寺院ばかりでなく、料理屋や文化人など民間でも広く嗜まれた。
sen.e: Fucha ryori was widely enjoyed for tasting exotic atmosphere rather than eating vegetarian dishes among the cultured people and ordinary people at restaurants as well as temples of the Obaku sect.

sen.j: 特に民間で行われた普茶料理は、長崎の卓袱料理とも影響し合い、テーブルクロスや貴重なガラス製のワイングラスや水差し、洋食器が用いられる事もしばしばあった。
sen.e: Especially fucha ryori served at ordinary restaurants and shippoku dish (a Japanized Chinese dish served on large plates from which diners help themselves) of Nagasaki had a mutual influence on each other, and a tablecloth, wineglasses made of expensive glass, a water jug, and Western tableware were often used.

sen.j: 料理そのものは次第に日本化していったが、既存の精進料理には無い鮮やかさや賑わいがあり、現在も作られている普茶料理は、見た目が鮮やかな独特のものに進化している。
sen.e: Dishes themselves have gradually been Japanized, and the fucha ryori today has been developed into the distinctive dishes with vivid color, which conventional vegetarian cuisine does not have.
